# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. ç¦æ­¢äº‹é …ç¢ºèª: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl â†’ Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py â†’ Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log â†’ Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

1â†’--- 2â†’url: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@vitejs/plugin-rsc 3â†’saved_at: 2025-08-24T21:18:14Z 4â†’title: @vitejs/plugin-rsc 5â†’domain: npmjs.com 6â†’--- 7â†’ 8â†’# @vitejs/plugin-rsc 9â†’ 10â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rsc) 11â†’ 12â†’This package provides [React Server Components](https://react.dev/reference/rsc/server-components) (RSC) support for Vite. 13â†’ 14â†’## Features 15â†’ 16â†’[](#features) 17â†’ 18â†’- **Framework-agnostic**: The plugin implements [RSC bundler features](https://react.dev/reference/rsc/server-components) and provides low level RSC runtime ( `react-server-dom`) API without framework-specific abstractions. 19â†’- **Runtime-agnostic**: Built on [Vite environment API](https://vite.dev/guide/api-environment.html) and works with other runtimes (e.g., [`@cloudflare/vite-plugin`](https://github.com/cloudflare/workers-sdk/tree/main/packages/vite-plugin-cloudflare)). 20â†’- **HMR support**: Enables editing both client and server components without full page reloads. 21â†’- **CSS support**: CSS is automatically code-split both at client and server components and they are injected upon rendering. 22â†’ 23â†’## Getting Started 24â†’ 25â†’[](#getting-started) 26â†’ 27â†’You can create a starter project by: 28â†’ 29â†’``` 30â†’npx degit vitejs/vite-plugin-react/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter my-app 31â†’``` 32â†’ 33â†’## Examples 34â†’ 35â†’[](#examples) 36â†’ 37â†’**Start here:** [`./examples/starter`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter) - Recommended for understanding the plugin 38â†’ 39â†’- Provides an in-depth overview of API with inline comments to explain how they function within RSC-powered React application. 40â†’ 41â†’**Integration examples:** 42â†’ 43â†’- [`./examples/basic`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/basic) - Advanced RSC features and testing 44â†’ - This is mainly used for e2e testing and includes various advanced RSC usages (e.g. `"use cache"` example). 45â†’- [`./examples/ssg`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/ssg) - Static site generation with MDX and client components for interactivity. 46â†’- [`./examples/react-router`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/react-router) - React Router RSC integration 47â†’ - Demonstrates how to integrate [experimental React Router RSC API](https://remix.run/blog/rsc-preview). React Router now provides [official RSC support](https://reactrouter.com/how-to/react-server-components), so it's recommended to follow React Router's official documentation for the latest integration. 48â†’ 49â†’## Basic Concepts 50â†’ 51â†’[](#basic-concepts) 52â†’ 53â†’This example is a simplified version of [`./examples/starter`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter). You can read [`./examples/starter/src/framework/entry.{rsc,ssr,browser}.tsx`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter/src/framework) for more in-depth commentary, which includes server function handling and client-side RSC re-fetching/re-rendering. 54â†’ 55â†’This is the diagram to show the basic flow of RSC rendering process. See also [https://github.com/hi-ogawa/vite-plugins/discussions/606](https://github.com/hi-ogawa/vite-plugins/discussions/606). 56â†’ 57â†’``` 58â†’graph TD 59â†’ 60â†’ subgraph "rsc environment" 61â†’ A["React virtual dom tree"] --> |"[@vitejs/plugin-rsc/rsc]
renderToReadableStream"| B1["RSC Stream"]; 62â†’ end 63â†’ 64â†’ B1 --> B2 65â†’ B1 --> B3 66â†’ 67â†’ subgraph "ssr environment" 68â†’ B2["RSC Stream"] --> |"[@vitejs/plugin-rsc/ssr]
createFromReadableStream"| C1["React virtual dom tree"]; 69â†’ C1 --> |"[react-dom/server]
SSR"| E["HTML String/Stream"]; 70â†’ end 71â†’ 72â†’ subgraph "client environment" 73â†’ B3["RSC Stream"] --> |"[@vitejs/plugin-rsc/browser]
createFromReadableStream"| C2["React virtual dom tree"]; 74â†’ C2 --> |"[react-dom/client]
CSR: mount, hydration"| D["DOM Elements"]; 75â†’ end 76â†’ 77â†’ style A fill:#D6EAF8,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 78â†’ style B1 fill:#FEF9E7,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 79â†’ style B2 fill:#FEF9E7,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 80â†’ style B3 fill:#FEF9E7,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 81â†’ style C1 fill:#D6EAF8,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 82â†’ style C2 fill:#D6EAF8,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 83â†’ style D fill:#D5F5E3,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 84â†’ style E fill:#FADBD8,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px 85â†’``` 86â†’ 87â†’- [`vite.config.ts`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter/vite.config.ts) 88â†’ 89â†’``` 90â†’import rsc from '@vitejs/plugin-rsc' 91â†’import { defineConfig } from 'vite' 92â†’ 93â†’export default defineConfig({ 94â†’ plugins: [ 95â†’ // add plugin 96â†’ rsc(), 97â†’ ], 98â†’ 99â†’ // specify entry point for each environment. 100â†’ environments: { 101â†’ // `rsc` environment loads modules with `react-server` condition. 102â†’ // this environment is responsible for: 103â†’ // - RSC stream serialization (React VDOM -> RSC stream) 104â†’ // - server functions handling 105â†’ rsc: { 106â†’ build: { 107â†’ rollupOptions: { 108â†’ input: { 109â†’ index: './src/framework/entry.rsc.tsx', 110â†’ }, 111â†’ }, 112â†’ }, 113â†’ }, 114â†’ 115â†’ // `ssr` environment loads modules without `react-server` condition. 116â†’ // this environment is responsible for: 117â†’ // - RSC stream deserialization (RSC stream -> React VDOM) 118â†’ // - traditional SSR (React VDOM -> HTML string/stream) 119â†’ ssr: { 120â†’ build: { 121â†’ rollupOptions: { 122â†’ input: { 123â†’ index: './src/framework/entry.ssr.tsx', 124â†’ }, 125â†’ }, 126â†’ }, 127â†’ }, 128â†’ 129â†’ // client environment is used for hydration and client-side rendering 130â†’ // this environment is responsible for: 131â†’ // - RSC stream deserialization (RSC stream -> React VDOM) 132â†’ // - traditional CSR (React VDOM -> Browser DOM tree mount/hydration) 133â†’ // - refetch and re-render RSC 134â†’ // - calling server functions 135â†’ client: { 136â†’ build: { 137â†’ rollupOptions: { 138â†’ input: { 139â†’ index: './src/framework/entry.browser.tsx', 140â†’ }, 141â†’ }, 142â†’ }, 143â†’ }, 144â†’ }, 145â†’}) 146â†’``` 147â†’ 148â†’- [`entry.rsc.tsx`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter/src/framework/entry.rsc.tsx) 149â†’ 150â†’``` 151â†’import { renderToReadableStream } from '@vitejs/plugin-rsc/rsc' 152â†’ 153â†’// the plugin assumes `rsc` entry having default export of request handler 154â†’export default async function handler(request: Request): Promise { 155â†’ // serialize React VDOM to RSC stream 156â†’ const root = ( 157â†’ 158â†’ 159â†’

160â†’ 161â†’ 162â†’ ) 163â†’ const rscStream = renderToReadableStream(root) 164â†’ 165â†’ // respond direct RSC stream request based on framework's convention 166â†’ if (request.url.endsWith('.rsc')) { 167â†’ return new Response(rscStream, { 168â†’ headers: { 169â†’ 'Content-type': 'text/x-component;charset=utf-8', 170â†’ }, 171â†’ }) 172â†’ } 173â†’ 174â†’ // delegate to SSR environment for html rendering 175â†’ // `loadModule` is a helper API provided by the plugin for multi environment interaction. 176â†’ const ssrEntry = await import.meta.viteRsc.loadModule< 177â†’ typeof import('./entry.ssr.tsx') 178â†’ >('ssr', 'index') 179â†’ const htmlStream = await ssrEntry.handleSsr(rscStream) 180â†’ 181â†’ // respond html 182â†’ return new Response(htmlStream, { 183â†’ headers: { 184â†’ 'Content-type': 'text/html', 185â†’ }, 186â†’ }) 187â†’} 188â†’``` 189â†’ 190â†’- [`entry.ssr.tsx`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter/src/framework/entry.ssr.tsx) 191â†’ 192â†’``` 193â†’import { createFromReadableStream } from '@vitejs/plugin-rsc/ssr' 194â†’import { renderToReadableStream } from 'react-dom/server.edge' 195â†’ 196â†’export async function handleSsr(rscStream: ReadableStream) { 197â†’ // deserialize RSC stream back to React VDOM 198â†’ const root = await createFromReadableStream(rscStream) 199â†’ 200â†’ // helper API to allow referencing browser entry content from SSR environment 201â†’ const bootstrapScriptContent = 202â†’ await import.meta.viteRsc.loadBootstrapScriptContent('index') 203â†’ 204â†’ // render html (traditional SSR) 205â†’ const htmlStream = renderToReadableStream(root, { 206â†’ bootstrapScriptContent, 207â†’ }) 208â†’ 209â†’ return htmlStream 210â†’} 211â†’``` 212â†’ 213â†’- [`entry.browser.tsx`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter/src/framework/entry.browser.tsx) 214â†’ 215â†’``` 216â†’import { createFromReadableStream } from '@vitejs/plugin-rsc/browser' 217â†’import { hydrateRoot } from 'react-dom/client' 218â†’ 219â†’async function main() { 220â†’ // fetch and deserialize RSC stream back to React VDOM 221â†’ const rscResponse = await fetch(window.location.href + '.rsc') 222â†’ const root = await createFromReadableStream(rscResponse.body) 223â†’ 224â†’ // hydration (traditional CSR) 225â†’ hydrateRoot(document, root) 226â†’} 227â†’ 228â†’main() 229â†’``` 230â†’ 231â†’## Environment helper API 232â†’ 233â†’[](#environment-helper-api) 234â†’ 235â†’The plugin provides an additional helper for multi environment interaction. 236â†’ 237â†’### Available on `rsc` or `ssr` environment 238â†’ 239â†’[](#available-on-rsc-or-ssr-environment) 240â†’ 241â†’#### `import.meta.viteRsc.loadModule` 242â†’ 243â†’[](#importmetaviterscloadmodule) 244â†’ 245â†’- Type: `(environmentName: "ssr" | "rsc", entryName: string) = > Promise < T >` 246â†’ 247â†’This allows importing `ssr` environment module specified by `environments.ssr.build.rollupOptions.input[entryName]` inside `rsc` environment and vice versa. 248â†’ 249â†’During development, by default, this API assumes both `rsc` and `ssr` environments execute under the main Vite process. When enabling `rsc({ loadModuleDevProxy: true })` plugin option, the loaded module is implemented as a proxy with `fetch` -based RPC to call in node environment on the main Vite process, which for example, allows `rsc` environment inside cloudflare workers to access `ssr` environment on the main Vite process. 250â†’ 251â†’During production build, this API will be rewritten into a static import of the specified entry of other environment build and the modules are executed inside the same runtime. 252â†’ 253â†’For example, 254â†’ 255â†’``` 256â†’// ./entry.rsc.tsx 257â†’const ssrModule = await import.meta.viteRsc.loadModule("ssr", "index"); 258â†’ssrModule.renderHTML(...); 259â†’ 260â†’// ./entry.ssr.tsx (with environments.ssr.build.rollupOptions.input.index = "./entry.ssr.tsx") 261â†’export function renderHTML(...) {} 262â†’``` 263â†’ 264â†’### Available on `rsc` environment 265â†’ 266â†’[](#available-on-rsc-environment) 267â†’ 268â†’#### `import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss` 269â†’ 270â†’[](#importmetaviterscloadcss) 271â†’ 272â†’> \[!NOTE\] 273â†’> The plugin automatically injects CSS for server components. See the [CSS Support](#css-support) section for detailed information about automatic CSS injection. 274â†’ 275â†’- Type: `(importer?: string) = > React.ReactNode` 276â†’ 277â†’This allows collecting css which is imported through a current server module and injecting them inside server components. 278â†’ 279â†’``` 280â†’import './test.css' 281â†’import dep from './dep.tsx' 282â†’ 283â†’export function ServerPage() { 284â†’ // this will include css assets for "test.css" 285â†’ // and any css transitively imported through "dep.tsx" 286â†’ return ( 287â†’ <> 288â†’ {import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss()} 289â†’ ... 290â†’ 291â†’ ) 292â†’} 293â†’``` 294â†’ 295â†’When specifying `loadCss( < id >)`, it will collect css through the server module resolved by `< id >`. 296â†’ 297â†’``` 298â†’// virtual:my-framework-helper 299â†’export function Assets() { 300â†’ return <> 301â†’ {import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss("/routes/home.tsx")} 302â†’ {import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss("/routes/about.tsx")} 303â†’ {...} 304â†’ 305â†’} 306â†’ 307â†’// user-app.tsx 308â†’import { Assets } from "virtual:my-framework-helper"; 309â†’ 310â†’export function UserApp() { 311â†’ return 312â†’ 313â†’ 314â†’ 315â†’ ... 316â†’ 317â†’} 318â†’``` 319â†’ 320â†’#### `< id >?vite-rsc-css-export= < name >` 321â†’ 322â†’[](#idvite-rsc-css-exportname) 323â†’ 324â†’This special query convention provides automatic injection of `import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss`. 325â†’ 326â†’For example, 327â†’ 328â†’``` 329â†’// my-route.tsx 330â†’export function Page(props) { 331â†’ return
...
332â†’} 333â†’ 334â†’// my-route.tsx?vite-rsc-css-export=Page 335â†’function Page(props) { 336â†’ return
...
337â†’} 338â†’ 339â†’function __Page(props) { 340â†’ return ( 341â†’ <> 342â†’ {import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss()} 343â†’ 344â†’ 345â†’ ) 346â†’} 347â†’ 348â†’export { __Page as Page } 349â†’``` 350â†’ 351â†’### Available on `ssr` environment 352â†’ 353â†’[](#available-on-ssr-environment) 354â†’ 355â†’#### `import.meta.viteRsc.loadBootstrapScriptContent("index")` 356â†’ 357â†’[](#importmetaviterscloadbootstrapscriptcontentindex) 358â†’ 359â†’This provides a raw js code to execute a browser entry file specified by `environments.client.build.rollupOptions.input.index`. This is intended to be used with React DOM SSR API, such as [`renderToReadableStream`](https://react.dev/reference/react-dom/server/renderToReadableStream) 360â†’ 361â†’``` 362â†’import { renderToReadableStream } from 'react-dom/server.edge' 363â†’ 364â†’const bootstrapScriptContent = 365â†’ await import.meta.viteRsc.loadBootstrapScriptContent('index') 366â†’const htmlStream = await renderToReadableStream(reactNode, { 367â†’ bootstrapScriptContent, 368â†’}) 369â†’``` 370â†’ 371â†’### Available on `client` environment 372â†’ 373â†’[](#available-on-client-environment) 374â†’ 375â†’#### `rsc:update` event 376â†’ 377â†’[](#rscupdate-event) 378â†’ 379â†’This event is fired when server modules are updated, which can be used to trigger re-fetching and re-rendering of RSC components on browser. 380â†’ 381â†’``` 382â†’import { createFromFetch } from '@vitejs/plugin-rsc/browser' 383â†’ 384â†’import.meta.hot.on('rsc:update', async () => { 385â†’ // re-fetch RSC stream 386â†’ const rscPayload = await createFromFetch(fetch(window.location.href + '.rsc')) 387â†’ // re-render ... 388â†’}) 389â†’``` 390â†’ 391â†’## Plugin API 392â†’ 393â†’[](#plugin-api) 394â†’ 395â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc` 396â†’ 397â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rsc-1) 398â†’ 399â†’``` 400â†’import rsc from '@vitejs/plugin-rsc' 401â†’import { defineConfig } from 'vite' 402â†’ 403â†’export default defineConfig({ 404â†’ plugins: [ 405â†’ rsc({ 406â†’ // this is only a shorthand of specifying each rollup input via 407â†’ // `environments[name].build.rollupOptions.input.index` 408â†’ entries: { 409â†’ rsc: '...', 410â†’ ssr: '...', 411â†’ client: '...', 412â†’ }, 413â†’ 414â†’ // by default, the plugin sets up middleware 415â†’ // using `default` export of `rsc` environment `index` entry. 416â†’ // this behavior can be customized by `serverHandler` option. 417â†’ serverHandler: false, 418â†’ 419â†’ // when `loadModuleDevProxy: true`, `import.meta.viteRsc.loadModule` is implemented 420â†’ // through `fetch` based RPC, which allows, for example, rsc environment inside 421â†’ // cloudflare workers to communicate with node ssr environment on main Vite process. 422â†’ loadModuleDevProxy: true, 423â†’ 424â†’ // by default, `loadCss()` helper is injected based on certain heuristics. 425â†’ // if it breaks, it can be opt-out or selectively applied based on files. 426â†’ rscCssTransform: { filter: (id) => id.includes('/my-app/') }, 427â†’ 428â†’ // by default, the plugin uses a build-time generated encryption key for 429â†’ // "use server" closure argument binding. 430â†’ // This can be overwritten by configuring `defineEncryptionKey` option, 431â†’ // for example, to obtain a key through environment variable during runtime. 432â†’ // cf. https://nextjs.org/docs/app/guides/data-security#overwriting-encryption-keys-advanced 433â†’ defineEncryptionKey: 'process.env.MY_ENCRYPTION_KEY', 434â†’ }), 435â†’ ], 436â†’}) 437â†’``` 438â†’ 439â†’## RSC runtime (react-server-dom) API 440â†’ 441â†’[](#rsc-runtime-react-server-dom-api) 442â†’ 443â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/rsc` 444â†’ 445â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rscrsc) 446â†’ 447â†’This module re-exports RSC runtime API provided by `react-server-dom/server.edge` and `react-server-dom/client.edge` such as: 448â†’ 449â†’- `renderToReadableStream`: RSC serialization (React VDOM - > RSC stream) 450â†’- `createFromReadableStream`: RSC deserialization (RSC stream - > React VDOM). This is also available on rsc environment itself. For example, it allows saving serialized RSC and deserializing it for later use. 451â†’- `decodeAction/decodeReply/decodeFormState/loadServerAction/createTemporaryReferenceSet` 452â†’- `encodeReply/createClientTemporaryReferenceSet` 453â†’ 454â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/ssr` 455â†’ 456â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rscssr) 457â†’ 458â†’This module re-exports RSC runtime API provided by `react-server-dom/client.edge` 459â†’ 460â†’- `createFromReadableStream`: RSC deserialization (RSC stream - > React VDOM) 461â†’ 462â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/browser` 463â†’ 464â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rscbrowser) 465â†’ 466â†’This module re-exports RSC runtime API provided by `react-server-dom/client.browser` 467â†’ 468â†’- `createFromReadableStream`: RSC deserialization (RSC stream - > React VDOM) 469â†’- `createFromFetch`: a robust way of `createFromReadableStream((await fetch("...")).body)` 470â†’- `encodeReply/setServerCallback`: server function related... 471â†’ 472â†’## High level API 473â†’ 474â†’[](#high-level-api) 475â†’ 476â†’> \[!NOTE\] 477â†’> High level API is deprecated. Please write on your own `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/{rsc,ssr,browser}` integration. 478â†’ 479â†’This is a wrapper of `react-server-dom` API and helper API to setup a minimal RSC app without writing own framework code like [`./examples/starter/src/framework`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/starter/src/framework/). See [`./examples/basic`](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/blob/HEAD/packages/plugin-rsc/examples/basic/) for how this API is used. 480â†’ 481â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/extra/rsc` 482â†’ 483â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rscextrarsc) 484â†’ 485â†’- `renderRequest` 486â†’ 487â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/extra/ssr` 488â†’ 489â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rscextrassr) 490â†’ 491â†’- `renderHtml` 492â†’ 493â†’### `@vitejs/plugin-rsc/extra/browser` 494â†’ 495â†’[](#vitejsplugin-rscextrabrowser) 496â†’ 497â†’- `hydrate` 498â†’ 499â†’## CSS Support 500â†’ 501â†’[](#css-support) 502â†’ 503â†’The plugin automatically handles CSS code-splitting and injection for server components. This eliminates the need to manually call [`import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss()`](#importmetaviterscloadcss) in most cases. 504â†’ 505â†’1. **Component Detection**: The plugin automatically detects server components by looking for: 506â†’ - Function exports with capital letter names (e.g., `export function Page() {}`) 507â†’ - Default exports that are functions with capital names (e.g., `export default function Page() {}`) 508â†’ - Const exports assigned to functions with capital names (e.g., `export const Page = () = > {}`) 509â†’1. **CSS Import Detection**: For detected components, the plugin checks if the module imports any CSS files ( `.css`, `.scss`, `.sass`, etc.) 510â†’1. **Automatic Wrapping**: When both conditions are met, the plugin wraps the component with a CSS injection wrapper: 511â†’ 512â†’``` 513â†’// Before transformation 514â†’import './styles.css' 515â†’ 516â†’export function Page() { 517â†’ return
Hello
518â†’} 519â†’ 520â†’// After transformation 521â†’import './styles.css' 522â†’ 523â†’export function Page() { 524â†’ return ( 525â†’ <> 526â†’ {import.meta.viteRsc.loadCss()} 527â†’
Hello
528â†’ 529â†’ ) 530â†’} 531â†’``` 532â†’ 533â†’## Canary and Experimental channel releases 534â†’ 535â†’[](#canary-and-experimental-channel-releases) 536â†’ 537â†’See [https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/pull/524](https://github.com/vitejs/vite-plugin-react/pull/524) for how to install the package for React [canary](https://react.dev/community/versioning-policy#canary-channel) and [experimental](https://react.dev/community/versioning-policy#all-release-channels) usages. 538â†’ 539â†’## Credits 540â†’ 541â†’[](#credits) 542â†’ 543â†’This project builds on fundamental techniques and insights from pioneering Vite RSC implementations. 544â†’Additionally, Parcel and React Router's work on standardizing the RSC bundler/app responsibility has guided this plugin's API design: 545â†’ 546â†’- [Waku](https://github.com/wakujs/waku) 547â†’- [@lazarv/react-server](https://github.com/lazarv/react-server) 548â†’- [@jacob-ebey/vite-react-server-dom](https://github.com/jacob-ebey/vite-plugins/tree/main/packages/vite-react-server-dom) 549â†’- [React Router RSC](https://remix.run/blog/rsc-preview) 550â†’- [Parcel RSC](https://parceljs.org/recipes/rsc) Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.

## é‡è¦ãªãƒã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒˆ:

1. **Runtime-agnostic**: `@cloudflare/vite-plugin`ã¨é€£æºå¯èƒ½
2. **loadModuleDevProxy**: Cloudflare Workerså†…ã®RSCç’°å¢ƒã‹ã‚‰Node.jsä¸Šã®SSRç’°å¢ƒã¨é€šä¿¡å¯èƒ½
3. **3ã¤ã®ã‚¨ãƒ³ãƒˆãƒªãƒ¼ãƒã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒˆ**:

# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. ç¦æ­¢äº‹é …ç¢ºèª: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl â†’ Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py â†’ Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log â†’ Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. ç¦æ­¢äº‹é …ç¢ºèª: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl â†’ Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py â†’ Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log â†’ Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. ç¦æ­¢äº‹é …ç¢ºèª: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl â†’ Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py â†’ Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log â†’ Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.
